title: Beeston Canal Walk Route

images.title: David Lally / Fishing by Beeston Lock
images.caption: Fishing by Beeston Lock. It's often busy around here at dinner-time with people from nearby factories and offices enjoying the waterside on their break. This was the first time I'd seen anyone fishing though.

images.title: David Lally / Cottages near Beeston Lock
images.caption: Cottages near Beeston Lock. Situated behind the lock-keeper cottage, these has been bordered up for some years.

images.title: Oxymoron / Willows Along the Beeston Canal
images.caption: Willows Along the Beeston Canal. There is a row of beautiful willow trees along a short stretch of the north bank of the Beeston canal in Beeston Rylands.

images.title: Oxymoron / Bridge Over the Beeston Canal
images.caption: Bridge Over the Beeston Canal. With the tops of a fine line of willow trees that line the north bank of the canal on the other side of the bridge visible at middle right.

images.title: J Beniston, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Canal bridge looking towards Nottingham

images.title: Mick Garratt / Beeston Canal
images.caption: Canal view approaching the city centre.

description: This walk takes you along the Beeston Canal in Nottingham. The towpath along the canal was completed in 1982 and is now used as an easy cycle or walking route. The walk starts from Beeston Lock on the River Trent near the city centre. From here you can pick up the canal towpath and follow it north east through Rylands and then on into the city centre. At the western end of the canal you'll find the Attenborough Nature Reserve. You could extend your walk by heading south west through the reserve where there are a number of lakes and lots of wildlife to look out for.

details.subtitle: Further Information and Other Local Ideas
details.content: To continue your waterside walking around the city you could pick up the Nottingham Canal. This will take you along the Erewash Valley Trail from Langley Mill to the outskirts of Nottingham. For more walking ideas in the area see the Nottinghamshire Walks page.
